entry.title: #1 future is a monad
entry.content:
We all know that scala futures are a monad... but could we wrap them using Scalaz Monad trait? Being able to do that would allow use all Scalaz abstractions with our loved scala futures.

It turns out to be a really easy task...

``` scala implicit val futureMonad = new Monad[Future] {

override def point[A](a: => A): Future[A] =
  future(a)

override def bind[A, B](fa: Future[A])(f: A => Future[B]): Future[B] =
  fa.flatMap(f)

} ```

Now we can do lot of fancy things as using the sequence method over a list of Monads:

``` scala def sequenceT, M[+_] : Monad: M[List[T]] =

implicitly[Monad[M]].sequence(l)

```

Or if you don't mind to add some more implicit magic into place:

``` scala package futuremonad

import scala.language.{ higherKinds, postfixOps }

import scala.concurrent. import scala.concurrent.ExecutionContext.Implicits.global import scala.concurrent.duration. import scala.collection.immutable._

import scalaz. import scalaz.std.list. import scalaz.syntax.monad. import scalaz.syntax.traverse.

object Monads extends App {

implicit val futureMonad = new Monad[Future] {

override def point[A](a: => A): Future[A] =
  future(a)

override def bind[A, B](fa: Future[A])(f: A => Future[B]): Future[B] =
  fa.flatMap(f)

}

val nums = (1 to 100) toStream val odds = nums filter (_ % 2 == 1) toList

val fls2 = odds.map(a => future(a*2)).sequence map (_.sum)

fls2 onSuccess {

case total => println(s"Sum of 2*odds: $total")

}

Await.ready(fls2, 5 seconds) } ```

The source code is available at https://github.com/lvicentesanchez.
